chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This is a jEdit plugin to perform spell checking of text in a jEdit buffer. It is based on Aspell (http://aspell.sourceforge.net/) (which you may need to download and install before using this plugin) which is available for Windows and various Unix platforms.

listitem.para: An jEdit action to spell check selected text or entire buffer if no selection.
An jEdit action to spell check selected text or entire buffer if no selection using an alternate lang dictionary.
Configurable location of Aspell executable.
Configurable main language dictionary (requires the correct installation of the corresponding language for Aspell).
Automatically (or manually) discards tags for all defined markup edit modes likes html, xml, ...

Spell check dialog to allow the user to validate each suspect word. The dialog has buttons for: Cancel, Change, Change All, Ignore, and Ignore All. It shows the suspect word, lists suggested replacements, and has a field where the user can type in the replacement word.
The plugin requires jEdit 4.3pre12 or later.
The plugin requires Java JDK 1.5.
Tested on Mac OS X, Windows XP and Linux.
Aspell 0.32.6 alpha or better (I am using Aspell 0.60.5).
First, you must have Aspell, as well as some dictionary installed.

glossdef.para: Aspell is not pre-installed on Windows. You can get it from Gnu: http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/aspell/w32/. The installer is Aspell-0-50-3-3-Setup.exe. The dictionary for your language of choice comes by the two letter ISO code of the language, like Aspell-fr-0.50-3-3.exe for French, or Aspell-uk-0.50-3-3.exe for UK English. These are installers, so you only have to execute the full installer, then the dictionary installer to be done with this.

Depending on your distribution, Aspell can be already present. You can check this by typing aspell -v in a terminal console. If you see something like @(#) International Ispell Version 3.1.20 (but really Aspell 0.60.5), it's OK.

If aspell is not present (you are getting -bash: aspell: command not found), use your package manager to install it automatically. Alternatively, you can get the source from http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/aspell/.

You should use Macports to get aspell. If you are already using Macports, all you have to do is sudo port install aspell. If you do not, there is some guidance on http://docs.moodle.org/en/Configuring_aspell_on_Mac_OS_X.

listitem.para: Use the Plugin Manager to download and install automatically the SpellCheck plugin.
Alternatively, copy the the SpellCheck.jar file to your jEdit jars directory (in that case, you will have to restart jEdit)
You should see a Spell Check entry on the Plugins menu.
In the Plugins -> Plugin Options... option dialog, section SpellCheck, there are some options to set. See Options chapter below.

chapter.title: Options
chapter.para: In the Plugins -> Plugin Options... option dialog, section SpellCheck, there are some options to set.

section.title: Aspell executable filename
section.para: It is important to set the Aspell executable filename to where you have installed aspell. If you didn't install it manually, try to leave it to "aspell".

listitem.para: On Windows it's in c:\Program Files\Aspell\bin
On Mac OS X it's in /opt/local/bin
On Linux it's in /usr/local/bin

section.title: Lang dictionary to use
section.para: You can choose in the dictionary list which dictionary to use for spell-checking. (the list is taken from aspell output, so Aspell executable path must be correctly set for that).

section.title: Markup Mode
section.para: Aspell is able to deal automatically with certain kinds of documents, via Filter Modes. Here is an extract of what aspell --help says on my computer:
section.programlisting:
Available Filter Modes: Filter Modes are reconfigured combinations of filters optimized for files of a specific type. A mode is selected via the "mode" option. This will happen implicitly if Aspell is able to identify the file type from the extension, and possibility the contents, of the file.
ccpp mode for checking C++ comments and string literals comment mode to check any lines starting with a # email mode for skipping quoted text in email messages html mode for checking HTML documents none mode to disable all filters nroff mode for checking Nroff documents perl mode for checking Perl comments and string literals sgml mode for checking generic SGML/XML documents tex mode for checking TeX/LaTeX documents texinfo mode for checking Texinfo documents url mode to skip URL like constructs (default mode)
section.para:
You can choose to
Disable Markup mode: it will tell Aspell not to use any filter. As a result, your buffer will be analysed as plain text
use Automatic Markup mode: it will let Aspell choose which mode to use automatically
use Manual Markup mode: it will tell Aspell which mode to use, according to your choices in the table bellow

If you choose the Manual Markup Mode, you will have to configure which aspell filter to use for each mode. Leave it to AUTO to let aspell choose. Use the filter named none to disable context-filtering at all.

section.title: Additional parameters
section.para: If you are familiar with Aspell from the command line and want to pass additional parameters, feel free to enter these parameters here. They will be directly passed to aspell. This way, you can use a personal dictionary, for instance...
Note however that the parameters are currently not allowed to contain white space.

section.title: Spell-check on save
section.para: This experimental feature takes advantage of the Error List plugin to report every misspelled word as a warning. Spell-checking is performed each time you save a file.
As you will soon discover, this can turn very annoying, because it's quickly sluggish. So : beware !

listitem.para: Select the text you would like to spell check (no selection will spell check all the buffer).

Choose the menu item Plugins -> Spell check -> Spell check selection... for default lang dictionary or Plugins -> Spell check -> Spell check selection with lang... to use an alternate lang dictionary.
You will be prompted with a MS-Office-like spell check dialog box for each word that needs to be validated.
See for more info on the dialog box.

section.title: Spell Check Dialog Box
section.para:
For each misspelled word the user has buttons to choose to:
Add (not in this version)
Adds the word not in the Not in Dictionary field to the dictionary.
Cancel
Closes the dialog box without making any changes you have made.
Change
Replaces the word in the Not in Dictionary text field with the word in the Change to text field. If the Change to text field is empty, the button name changes to Delete. To remove the selected word from the item, click Delete.
Change All
Replaces all instances of the word not in the Not in Dictionary text field with the word in the Change to text field. If the Change to text field is empty, the button name changes to Delete All. To remove all instances of the selected word from the item, click Delete.
Ignore
Leaves the word in the Not in Dictionary text field unchanged.
Ignore All
Leaves all instances of the word in the Not in Dictionary text field unchanged.

The dialog has the following components:
Not in Dictionary
Displays a possible error, such as a misspelled word, a duplicate word, or a incorrect capitalization.
Change to:
Displays a suggested word to replace the word that appears in the Not in Dictionary text field. To accept the suggested replacement, click Change. To delete the word in the Not in Dictionary text field, delete the text in the Change to text field, and then click Delete.
Suggestions:
Lists suggested replacement words.

chapter.title: Building
chapter.para: As of release R005, the build process is the same as other plugins. It uses the build-support/plugin-build.xml build file, available from jedit repository. The documentation is generated using docbook xsl.

listitem.para: It has happened once that jEdit froze while was active. If you encounter such behaviour again, please send a bug report.
Add words to an user dictionary
Allow the user to reset Ignore All and Change All options (currently these are result only if jEdit is restarted)
Undo a change : for now, one can only cancel the whole spell-checking but not undo the last action.
Allow the user access all of Aspell options
Highlight the context of the word being corrected. This is partially fixed in R005. It doesn't scroll to show the word yet, because of bug #1990960 in jEdit.
Use the output of aspell dump modes in Option pane: it would be nice to output in some way the description of the modes from Aspell.
Try to use VoxSpell plugin in some way (as another engine ?).
Release 005 (June, 2008) - E.Le Lay
Fix: bug [787498] : SpellCheck freeze. Now SpellCheck shouldn't freeze the editor any more. (If it does, please report !)
Fix: the currently spell-checked word is highlighted
Updated for jEdit 4.3 API (dynamic loading, local data)
Add the ability to define the language for each buffer.
Really use mode-filters (fix for bug [898733] SpellCheck does not discard markup).
Add the ability to report misspellings as warnings in ErrorList
Release 004 (Jul 25, 2002) - L.Fiol
Fix: the current buffer is no more changed when there were no spell errors corrected in the buffer. Instead a status message tells there were nothing to correct.
Fix: the last line separator of the selection which is spell checked is removed if any.
Fix: Exception was thrown when there was no suggestion for a word.
Updated for jEdit 4.0 API.
Spell checks for entire buffer when no selection.
If the Aspell executable field is empty it is defaulted to 'Aspell' on Unix systems. On others systems an open file dialog is displayed. The Aspell executable property is saved afterward.
Add the ability to choose another language dictionary than the default one (use both the --lang and --language-tag parameters as some systems seems to need the first and others the second).
Add the ability to choose to automatically discard tags in all defined markup edit modes.
Add the ability to specify any additional Aspell parameter.
Release 003 (Sep 09, 2001)
Same functionality as R002, but now in SourceForge's CVS.
Cleaned and improved the build.xml and build.cmd files.
Release 002 (Apr 22, 2001)
Added build files (build.xml and makefile.jmk) to distribution
Updated help.html with test feedback and system requirements
The ValidationDialog now remembers its last placement. This means that once you move it out-of-the-way, it stays out-of-the-way.
